entry.title: üåª AI friends too cheap to meter)
entry.content: That‚Äôs why it bothers me when tech critics describe AI as exclusively foisted upon us by corporate overlords. They deploy violent physical metaphors to make the case: Brian Merchant says tech companies are ‚Äúforce-feeding‚Äù us, Cory Doctorow says it‚Äôs being ‚Äúcrammed down throats,‚Äù and Ted Gioia analogizes AI companies to tyrants telling peons to ‚Äúshut up, buddy, and chew.‚Äù In their story, everyone hates AI and nobody chooses to use it; each one of ChatGPT‚Äôs 700 million users is effectively being waterboarded, unable to escape.

entry.title: Everyone is illiterate now (conference reviewing rant)
entry.content: It really just seems like researchers can‚Äôt (or won‚Äôt) read carefully anymore. Some authors failed to identify major relevant literature from the proceedings of the very conference they were submitting to. Others simply didn‚Äôt bother to add citations to work they described directly and referred to by name. Even some of the other conference reviewers spoke in platitudes rather than point out specific parts of the paper that exemplified the points they were making. (The submissions have line numbers! They are in red!!)

entry.title: my coworker mansplains via ChatGPT
entry.content: Reader writes: These AI answers are often band-aid fixes that miss the entire point of me asking for context or detail on a problem to understand the root cause. Like if I had asked, ‚ÄúI have noticed a hole in the llama containment fence, the damage suggests vandals, has that historically been an issue, and should we look into deterring them or put up cameras?‚Äù the ChatGPT guy will reply with, ‚ÄúChatGPT says we can patch the hole with a fence repair kit.‚Äù

entry.title: The Boomerfication of Gen Z | Internet Analysis
entry.content: Tiffany Ferg had some great insight into the online trend of Gen Z supposedly becoming Boomer-like.

entry.title: The Rise and Fall of 'the Resistance'
entry.content: In 2017, the Resistance movement exploded across America with massive protests, hashtags, and nonstop anti-Trump content. The Resistance birthed a powerful group of anti-Trump influencers, podcasts, Twitter accounts, and personalities. But fast forward to today and Liberals have all but stopped resisting. Resistance influencers who once railed against Trump now openly support him, and progressive movements have been significantly hollowed out. What happened?

entry.title: What does the Social Content Fracture Mean??
entry.content:
Is it a good thing or a bad thing for the sort of health and well-being of culture and humanity for us to move away from super centralized platforms?

[T]here is also like a chance that there‚Äôs going to be good parts to this, that having fringe ideas exist in fringe spaces is how it‚Äôs always been and that was better, both because having fringe ideas in normal spaces normalizes them, and that does two things. It makes it so it feels like it‚Äôs okay to believe those ideas and, and two, it makes it easy to pull those ideas out and ascribe them to all of your opposition.

entry.title: Steve Jobs on the downfall of dominant companies.
entry.content: If you are a product person at IBM or Xerox, so you make a better copier or a better computer, so what? When you have a monopoly market share the company‚Äôs not any more successful. So the people that can make the company more successful are the sales and marketing people, and they end up running the companies. And the product people get driven out of the decision making forums, and the companies forget what it means to make great products. Sort of the product sensibility and the product genius that brought them to that monopolistic position gets rotted out by people running these companies who have no conception of a good product versus a bad product.

entry.title: ‚ÄúWait, not like that‚Äù: Free and open access in the age of generative AI
entry.content:
There‚Äôs also been an impulse by creators concerned about AI to dramatically limit how people can access their work. Some artists have decided it‚Äôs simply not worthwhile to maintain an online gallery of their work when that makes it easily accessible for AI training. Many have implemented restrictive content gates ‚Äî paywalls, registration-walls, ‚Äúare you a human‚Äù-walls, and similar ‚Äî to try to fend off scrapers. This too closes off the commons, making it more challenging or expensive for those ‚Äúevery single human beings‚Äù described in open access manifestos to access the material that was originally intended to be common goods.

Often by trying to wall off those considered to be bad actors, people wall off the very people they intended to give access to. People who gate their work behind paywalls likely didn‚Äôt set out to create works that only the wealthy could access. People who implement registration walls probably didn‚Äôt intend for their work to only be available to those willing to put up with the risk of incessant email spam after they relinquish their personal information. People who try to stave off bots with CAPTCHAs asking ‚Äúare you a human?‚Äù probably didn‚Äôt mean to limit their material only to abled people who are willing to abide ever more protracted and irritating riddles.8 And people using any of these strategies likely didn‚Äôt want people to struggle to even find their work in the first place after the paywalls and regwalls and anti-bot mechanisms thwarted search engine indexers or social media previews.
